Authors:
Jing Li, Fujun Shen, Liang Zhang, Yaoyao Cui, Juan Jiang,
Jianqiu Yu, Lili Niu, Jiabo Deng, Bisong Yue, Jing Li
Title:
An application of DNA barcoding to conservation practice: a
case study of endangered birds and big mammals in China
Keywords:
DNA barcoding; Cytochrome c Oxidase subunit I (COI);
species identification; conservation practice; birds; mammals
Abstract:
Owning to its advantages over morphological method, DNA
barcoding could be a promising tool for species identification in
biodiversity conservation practice. To illustrate how to utilize DNA
barcoding for species identification of unknown samples in real
conservation work, we surveyed a case study of DNA barcoding for
endangered birds and big mammals in China. Covered species information,
47 birds and 39 mammals were re-identified by DNA barcoding with
sequential analyses of online species assignment, genetic distances and
phylogenetic reconstruction, and diagnostic nucleotide method. With this
multiple analyses strategy, all queries were efficiently assigned to
species level except for four samples to genus level. And 78.72% of bird
samples and 92.31% of mammal individuals got consistent identifications
with morphological classification. For those inconsistent
classification, we found some potential morphological misidentifications
and mislabelling with robust DNA barcoding evidence. And there are some
factors impacting the efficiency of DNA barcoding application, such as
sharing barcode and lacking conspecific barcodes. Our survey not only
showed a successful application of DNA barcoding to conservation
practice and enriched the barcode database, but also indicated our
analytical protocol can be recommended as an efficient and practical
identification method for routine work in conservation and many other
fields.
